trial_identification.studytitle: The effects of carbohydrates on the exercise-induced responses of stress hormones
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A crossover study of the effect of carbohydrate supplementation on the exercise-induced rise in stress hormone concentrations in healthy volunteers

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal metabolism and endocrine development and function

interventions.interventions: Participants will consume a liquid carbohydrate drink (40 grams in 600 milliliters) or liquid placebo immediately before and during completion of a one hour session of resistance exercise. Salivary hormones and plasma markers will be monitored at several time points including before and after exercise, later the same day, and for the two following days. A washout period of seven days will be used between treatments.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Salivary cortisol responses to exercise following beverage consumption
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Every 15 minutes before, during, and after exercise for 4 1/2 hours

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Plasma cytokine and protein responses to exercise following beverage consumption
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Immediately before and after exercise, 90 minutes after exercise completion, and 24 and 48 hours later

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Healthy males with at least one year of resistance exercise training experience
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Smoker, unable to exercise, history of anabolic steroid use, currently taking any supplements

trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation by using a software-generated randomisation table

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: The New Zealand Institute for Plant and Food Research Ltd. (Plant & Food Research)
